By James Bithell

The Trial

The performance erred too much on the side of the grotesque rather than the uncanny, but it is an interesting and highly watchable piece.

Butley

By James Bithell

Adam Alcock's remarkable production is both witty and refreshing, serving as a brilliant close to this term's season at the Drama Barn.

By James Bithell

There's nothing to unseat what develops into a highly competent, thought-provoking and watchable interpretation of Berkoff's Kafka.

By James Bithell

Chris Addison's comedy to be as hit-and-miss as his persona was inconsistent.

The portrait artist has painted her mothers corpse, and Prince Charles, but she tells Sophie Walker why she is never satisfied

<em>Celia Scruby</em> Investigates the role of creativity Vs. science within public art installation

A Midsummer Night's Dream

Slapstick humour and outlandish costumes make this adaptation one for the kids, but the director sacrifices any real resemblance to the original text

The House of Bernada Alba

Two superb hours of almost claustrophobic familiarity, set in the hidden world of spanish women pre-civil war

Scooped

A primary colour theme, but delivered with first-class style.

By James Bithell

Suddenly Last Summer

By James Bithell

This production of Tennessee Williams' stark and highly poetic one-act play is impressive, yet displayed regrettable moments of weakness.

Waiting for Godot

By James Bithell

For a play in which, infamously, 'nothing happens, twice', this compelling and darkly comic piece passed astonishingly quickly.

Al Murray: An Interview

By James Bithell

Pint-pulling comedian Al Murray talks to James Harle about getting political, the importance of history, and the joys of being a student.

Unknown Ritual

The Norman Rea Gallery's new exhibition blends ancient myth and human calamity to explain the phenomenon of ritual, and to ultimately question: What is death? What comes after it?

Our National Treasure

After a summer of 'wedding fever', the Royal Collection has been given a re-vamp. With the Queen's Diamond Jubilee approaching in 2012, what new artistic direction will the Collection take to celebrate it?

The Saliva Milkshake

This imaginatively assembled play was half an hour of political paranoia, beautifully minimalistic setting and quiet yet powerful acting.

Thoroughly Modern Millie

Happily Ever After Society's production of Thoroughly Modern Millie is an impressive evening of glamourous 20's entertainment.

Heading North

The contemporary art scene is moving away from the capital, Martin Waugh investigates

Kafka's Legacy

Emily Steinhauer finds the joint international venture to secure Kafka's letters bodes well for the decline of the private buyer

De Vere or Shakespere

"Illiterate", "drunkard", "fraud" - not descriptions we would usually apply to the world's most prolific writer

After Miss Julie

<em>After Miss Julie</em> provides a tense, dialogue-driven and enjoyable hour-and-a-half at the Barn this weekend, presenting us with some concentrated, skilled performances

The Accrington Pals

The Accrington Pals lacks direction at points but is lift by the high quality of acting. A welcome slice of northern drama to start the term. Rating: ***

King Lear

Shakespeare's darkest play has been brought to life with passion, clarity and attention to detail by director Ian Brown

By James Bithell

The Lure of the Library

Since April of this year, 415 public libraries have either already been closed, or faced imminent threat. Just what is it that lured people into libraries, and can they still mean something to us today?
